non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|theihs.org}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} The '''Institute for Humane Studies''' ('''IHS''') is a [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] [[non-profit organization]] that offers educational{{cite book|last=Hamowy|first=Ronald|title=The Encyclopedia of Libertarianism|year=Aug 15, 2008| pages=217,443 |publisher=SAGE|location=Thousand Oaks, California|isbn=978-1-4129-6580-4|url=http://books.google.com/?id=yxNgXs3TkJYC&dq=libertarian+encyclopedia}}{{cite news | title=The Acton Institute: Of Morality & the Marketplace | work=Grand Rapids Magazine | date=August 1999 | author=Convissor, Kate | location=Grand Rapids, Michigan | pages=36–37}}{{cite book | title=I Chose Liberty: Autobiographies of Contemporary Libertarians | publisher=Ludwig von Mises Institute | author=Block, Walter | year=2010 | location=Auburn, Alabama | page=429 | isbn=978-1-61016-002-5}}{{cite book | title=The Scholarship Scouting Report: An Insider's Guide to America's Best Scholarships | publisher=HarperResource | author=Kaplan, Benjamin R | year=2003 | location=New York | page=357 | isbn=978-0-06-093654-9}} and career programs. The educational programs include [[seminars]]{{cite web | url=http://scrippsjschool.org/news/scrippsNotes.php?id=2878 | title=2012 IHS Graduate Summer Seminars | publisher=E. W. Scripps School of Journalism | work=Ohio University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://web.archive.org/web/20100728073729/http://www.spn.org/about/student-opportunities | title=Student Opportunities | publisher=State Policy Network | work=eResources | accessdate=December 29, 2011}} for university students, awarding scholarships{{cite web | url=http://web.archive.org/web/20080618025444/http://opsf.byu.edu/Scholarships/InstituteHumane.aspx | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=Office of Prestigious Scholarships & Fellowships | work=Brigham Young University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://web.archive.org/web/20101130035448/http://syr.edu/financialaid/scholarships/external_scholarships/general/humane_studies.html | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=Office of Financial Aid and Scholarship Programs | work=Syracuse University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}}{{cite web | url=http://web.archive.org/web/20100422231914/http://www.lehigh.edu/~infao/current/types/scholarships.html | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=Office of Financial Aid | work=Lehigh University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}}{{cite web | url=https://researchfunding.duke.edu/detail.asp?OppID=4010 | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=Office of Funding Opportunities | work=Duke University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}} to [[undergraduate]] and [[Graduate school|graduate]] students, an interactive website based on a [[Political spectrum|multi-axis model of political thought]], and an archive of recorded [[lectures]]. The career assistance programs include paid [[internships]] for students and recent graduates, recognition of [[alumni]] accomplishments, and a [[social network|networking]] website for [[classical liberal]] [[Academia|academics]]. Founded by [[F. A. Harper|F. A. "Baldy" Harper]] in 1961{{cite news | url=http://mises.org/daily/2634 | title=Floyd Arthur 'Baldy' Harper, RIP | work=Mises Daily Index | date=August 17, 2007 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=Rothbard, Murray N | location=Auburn, Alabama}} Quote: "and he moved to transfer the bulk of the Volker funds to a new Institute for Humane Studies, which would expand the Volker concept and would provide a permanent home for libertarian fellowships, scholarship, conferences, and publications."{{cite book | title=Libertarianism Today | publisher=ABC-CLIO | author=Huebert, Jacob H | year=2010 | location=Santa Barbara, California | page=18 | isbn=978-0-313-37754-9}} Quote: "The Institute for Humane Studies (IHS), founded by F.A. Harper in 1961 to promote libertarian scholarship..."{{cite journal | url=http://www.thefreemanonline.org/featured/the-writings-of-f-a-harper/ | title=The Writings of F. A. Harper | author=Poirot, Paul L | journal=The Freeman | year=1979 | month=August | volume=29 | issue=8}}, the organization later began an association with [[George Mason University]] and in 1985{{Cite book | publisher = Institute of Economic Affairs | isbn = 978-0-255-36547-5 | last = Blundell | first = John | title = Waging the War of Ideas | date = 2003 }} moved to [[Fairfax, Virginia]]. The institute is currently located in Hazel Hall on the [[Arlington, Virginia|Arlington]]{{cite news | title=Koch's low profile belies political power | work=Center for Public Integrity's iwatch news | date=July 15, 2004 | author=Bogardus, Kevin | location=Washington, DC|url=http://www.publicintegrity.org/2004/07/15/5967/kochs-low-profile-belies-political-power}}{{cite news | url=http://foundationcenter.org/pnd/jobs/job_item.jhtml?id=341100054 | title=Jobs | work=Philanthropy News Digest | date=June 7, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | location=New York}} campus of George Mason University. ==History== [[File:Gmu law school.jpg|thumb|right|280px|Hazel Hall, home of the [[Mercatus Center]] and the Institute for Humane Studies on the [[George Mason University]] Arlington campus]] The Institute for Humane Studies was founded in 1961 in [[Menlo Park, California]] by [[F. A. Harper|F. A. "Baldy" Harper]], in his [[Garage (house)|garage]], in order to promote [[peace]], [[prosperity]], and [[social harmony]] by fostering a greater understanding of [[Social science|human affairs]] and [[Liberty|freedom]]. {{Cite book | publisher = Continuum International Publishing Group | isbn = 978-0-8264-4513-1 | last = Gladstein | first = Mimi Reisel | coauthors = John Meadowcroft | title = Ayn Rand | date = 2009-11-19 }} Initially serving as the secretary and treasurer, Harper became the Institute's president in 1966, a position he held until his death in 1973.[http://mises.org/resources/4903/The-Writings-of-F-A-Harper-Volume-1-The-Major-Works The Writings of F. A. Harper, Volume 1: The Major Works] The Writings of F. A. Harper, Volume 1: The Major Works, 1978 Following Harper in the role of president were Louis M. Spadaro and [[Leonard Liggio]], who served as president from 1980 to 1989. {{Cite book | publisher = NYU Press | isbn = 978-0-8147-7559-2 | last = Rothbard | first = Murray Newton | coauthors = Hans-Hermann Hoppe | title = The Ethics of Liberty | date = 2003-02 }} From 1998 to 2000 [[Stanford University|Stanford]] graduate David C. Nott, now with the [[Reason Foundation]], led the organization as president.{{Cite news | last = Levine | first = Rob | title = Person Profile | work = Media Transparency | accessdate = 2012-02-05 | url = http://old.mediatransparency.org/personprofile.php?personID=684 }} The current president [[Marty Zupan]], a former editor of [[Reason magazine|''Reason'' magazine]], was appointed in 2001, after serving as vice-president since 1989.{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Fred|title=Out of the Mouths of Babes: The Infant Formula Controversy|year=Aug 1, 1983|publisher=Transaction Publishers|location=Piscataway, New Jersey|isbn=978-0-912051-01-7|page=98|url=http://books.google.com/?id=LFfuaAdCdiAC&dq=%22Marty+Zupan%22}} After beginning an association with [[George Mason University]], Liggio, Walter Grinder, and [[John Blundell (economist)|John Blundell]] moved the institute to [[Fairfax, Virginia]] in 1985. The organization is currently located in Hazel Hall on the George Mason University [[Arlington, Virginia|Arlington]] campus, along with sister organization the [[Mercatus Center]]. ==Organization and funding== The institute is governed by a board of directors, currently chaired by [[Charles G. Koch]].{{cite web | url=http://www.greenpeace.org/usa/en/campaigns/global-warming-and-energy/polluterwatch/koch-industries/institute-for-humane-studies/ | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=Greenpeace | work=What We Do | accessdate=December 29, 2011}} The other members of the board of directors are [[John Blundell (economist)|John Blundell]], [[Richard H. Fink]], Jerome Fullinwider, Timothy Otis Browne, [[Tyler Cowen]], [[Art Pope]], David Humphreys, [[Eric O'Keefe (political activist)|Eric O'Keefe]], [[Todd Zywicki]], William Sumner, Kristina Kendall, and Craig Johnson.{{cite web|url=http://www2.guidestar.org/organizations/c/94-1623852/institute-humane-studies.aspx |title=Institute for Humane Studies |publisher=Guidestar.org |date= |accessdate=2011-11-21}} IHS has received funding from a number of foundations, including the [[Sarah Scaife Foundation]], the [[Koch Family Foundations]], and the [[Lynde and Harry Bradley Foundation]].{{cite web|url=http://bridgeproject.com/?organization&id=270906 |title=Recipient: Institute for Humane Studies |publisher=[[Media Matters for America|American Bridge 21st Century Foundation]]|date= |accessdate=2012-09-02}} In March 2012, in the midst of a legal dispute between [[Charles Koch]] and the [[Cato Institute]] that caused renewed scrutiny of Koch's political philanthropy, IHS's chief financial officer told the ''New York Times'' that Koch is "a longtime and generous supporter of ours, but we’re not involved as a political organization."{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/06/us/cato-institute-and-koch-in-rift-over-independence.html?pagewanted=1&ref=catoinstitute |title=Cato Institute Is Caught in a Rift Over Its Direction|publisher=New York Times|date=2012-03-06 |accessdate=2012-03-06}} ==Programs== ===Seminars=== [[File:Aristotle's Error.jpg|thumb|John Hasnas [[Lecture|lecturing]] at [[Towson University]] during a [[seminar]]]] Each summer, IHS runs a series of free, week-long summer seminars for university students from around the world. Seminars are interdisciplinary and include lectures on [[history]], [[economics]], [[philosophy]], [[law]], and [[political science]].{{Cite book | publisher = ISI Books | isbn = 978-1-932236-43-9 | last = Frohnen | first = Bruce | coauthors = Jeremy Beer, Jeffrey O. Nelson | title = American Conservatism: An Encyclopedia | date = 2006 }}{{cite news | url=http://stopthedrugwar.org/trenches/2007/feb/27/call_ssdpers_institute_humane_st | title=Call to SSDPers: Institute for Humane Studies (IHS) Summer Seminars | work=In the Trenches | date=February 27, 2007 | accessdate=12 December 2011 | author=Guard, David | newspaper=Stop the Drug War.org | location=Washington, DC}} Seminar themes include the value of [[property|property rights]], [[limited government]], [[peace]], [[natural rights]], [[free trade]], [[Self-ownership|individual autonomy]], and [[free market]]s. There are introductory and advanced seminars, as well as seminars geared toward students planning careers in [[public policy]], [[academia]], and [[journalism]]. IHS also runs weekend on-campus seminars during the academic year. IHS and [[Liberty Fund]] co-sponsor the Advanced Topics in Liberty program, which is an invitation-only, discussion-based weekend conference series.{{cite web | url=http://www.collegecentral.com/campbell/BulletinDetail.CFM?MessageID=64850&UnivCode=CAM | title=Institute for Humane Studies | publisher=College Central Network Services | work=Campbell University | accessdate=December 29, 2011}} For graduate students pursuing academic careers, IHS sponsors invitation-only Career Development Seminars designed to help students "land a job in academia, gain tenure, and contribute to the academic and intellectual conversation." ===Scholarships=== Through its Humane Studies Fellowship program, IHS awards scholarships to undergraduate and graduate students embarking on "liberty-advancing careers in ideas." Each summer, through the Summer Graduate Research Fellowship, IHS gives $5,000 stipends to young academics "to refine and complete a publishable scholarly article or thesis chapter that engages ideas within the classical liberal tradition." In the ''[[Daily Caller]]'', Matthew Zwolinski wrote that IHS trains professors to expose students to libertarian ideas: "[IHS] mentors graduate students through the process of finishing their classes and writing their dissertations. And it helps them find jobs. In the 50 years of its existence, IHS has put over 1,200 professors into classrooms across the country where they teach over a quarter of a million students each year. And those students are exposed to libertarian ideas not just in a 30-second advertisement or debate answer, but for an entire semester, rigorously and in depth."{{cite web | url=http://dailycaller.com/2012/01/12/libertarians-stop-worrying-about-ron-paul/ | title=Libertarians: Stop worrying about Ron Paul| publisher=[[Daily Caller]] |date=January 12, 2012|accessdate=October 2, 2012}} ===Online projects=== {{Annotated image | float=right | caption= Politopia.com is designed around analysis of political positions by [[Duquesne University]] economics professor Antony Davies{{Cite paper| last = Davies| first = Antony| title = Who favors more freedom, liberals or conservatives? | LearnLiberty| location = Fairfax, VA, US| accessdate = 2012-06-23| date = 2011-07-15| url = http://www.learnliberty.org/content/who-favors-more-freedom-liberals-or-conservatives}}| image=2d political spectrum.svg | annotations = {{Annotation|25|25|'''[[Economic freedom]]'''}}{{Annotation|95|120|[[Conservatism]]}}{{Annotation|205|90|[[Classical liberalism]]}}{{Annotation|105|200|[[Progressivism in the United States|Progressivism]]}}{{Annotation|55|230|[[Authoritarianism]]}}{{Annotation|165|150|[[Modern liberalism in the United States|Modern
Liberalism]]}}{{Annotation|170|270|'''[[Civil liberties|Personal freedom]]'''}}}} In 2010, IHS launched LearnLiberty.org, a website providing educational videos on [[Libertarianism|libertarian]] ideas.{{cite news | url=http://www.forbes.com/sites/artcarden/2011/08/25/the-earthquake-wasnt-good-for-the-economy-hurricane-irene-wont-be-either/ | title=The Earthquake Wasn't Good for the Economy. Hurricane Irene Won't Be, Either | work=Forbes | date=Aug 25, 2011 | accessdate=January 05, 2012 | author=Carden, Art | location=New York}}{{cite news | url=http://www.intellectualtakeout.org/blog/learnlibertyorg-launches | title=LearnLiberty.org Launches! | work=Intellectual Takeout | date=March 1, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=Foley, Devin | location=Minneapolis, Minnesota}}{{cite news | url=http://volokh.com/2011/06/29/learnliberty-org/ | title=LearnLiberty.org Launches! | work=The Volokh Conspiracy | date=June 29, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=Kerr,Orin | location=Los Angeles}} The site's stated goals are “to provide a starting point for conversations on important questions: What is the nature of man and society? What are the best ways to organize human society? What is the proper role for government?” Notable guest lecturers featured on LearnLiberty include [[David Schmidtz]] of the [[University of Arizona]] and [[Jeffrey Miron]] of [[Harvard University]].{{cite news | url=http://www.cato-at-liberty.org/top-3-common-myths-of-capitalism/ | title=Top 3 Common Myths of Capitalism | work=Cato @ Liberty | date=August 23, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=Graves, Zachary | location=Washington, DC}} IHS also operates Politopia.com, an educational interactive website based on the [[Nolan Chart]].{{cite book | title=Eight Ways to Run the Country: A New and Revealing Look at Left and Right | publisher=Greenwood Publishing Group | author=Mitchell, Brian Patrick | year=2007 | location=Westport, Connecticut | page=161 | isbn=978-0-275-99358-0}} Through a series of questions, the website places participants on a four-sided political map. Its purpose is to help individuals conceptualize political views. IHS maintains Kosmosonline.org, a networking website for classical liberal academics.{{cite news | url=http://web.archive.org/web/20110120195828/http://volokh.com/2010/11/08/podcast-at-kosmos-online/ | title=Podcast at Kosmos Online | work=Volokh Conspiracy | date=November 8, 2010 | accessdate=January 05, 2012 | author=Zywicki, Todd | location=Los Angeles}} The site's goal is to "provide career advice and intellectual resources for liberty advancing academics." The term "kosmos" comes from [[Friedrich Hayek|Friedrich Hayek's]] use of the term in [[Law, Legislation and Liberty]].{{cite book | title=Law, Legislation and Liberty: A New Statement of the Liberal Principles of Justice and Political Economy | publisher=Routledge | author=Hayek, F A | year=1982 | location=London | page=191 | isbn=0-7100-9211-3}} ===Internships=== [[File:Koch Summer Fellows Waiting for the Train.jpg|thumb|Koch Summer Fellows waiting for a [[Subway train|Subway Train]]]] Each summer, IHS runs the [[Charles G. Koch]] Summer Fellow Program. The program runs for 10 weeks, and includes a paid public policy internship with two career and policy seminars. Fellows are placed at one of 80 partner think tanks and policy organizations across the United States.{{cite web | url=http://www.empirecenter.org/AboutUs/Opportunities/2011/01/internship122809.cfm | title=Internships | publisher=Empire Center for New York State Policy | work=News |date=November 21, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011}} IHS also runs a year-round journalism internship program that places aspiring journalists who support individual liberty, free markets, and peace at media companies and non-profit newsrooms. ===Alum award=== Each year, IHS awards an alumnus of its programs with the Charles G. Koch Outstanding IHS Alum Award. The award is given in recognition of "significant contributions to advancing liberty."{{cite news | url=http://www.counterpunch.org/2011/09/12/the-koch-whisperers/ | title=The Koch Whisperers | work=CounterPunch | date=SEPTEMBER 12, 2011 | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=Martens, Pam | location=Petrolia, California}} Past award winners include libertarian legal theorist and law professor [[Randy Barnett]]; Kris Mauren, co-founder of the [[Acton Institute]]; law professor [[Todd Zywicki]]; Kristina Kendall, executive producer for [[John Stossel]]; political science professor John Tomasi; [[Scott Bullock]], senior attorney at the [[Institute for Justice]]; economist [[Peter Boettke]]; John Hood, president of the [[John Locke Foundation]]; and [[David Schmidtz]], a professor of philosophy and economics.{{cite conference | url=http://www.aei.org/events/print/us-regulatory-policy-and-free-enterprise | title=The Surprising Return of Price Controls | publisher=American Enterprise Institute and the National Chamber Foundation | accessdate=December 29, 2011 | author=DeMuth, Christopher | editor=Schulz, Nick | booktitle=The Impact on Economic Recovery | year=2010 | month=July | conference=U.S. Regulatory Policy and Free Enterprise | location=U.S. Chamber of Commerce}}{{cite journal | url=http://www.ij.org/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1976&Itemid=245 | title=IJ Attorney Scott Bullock Wins Koch Award | journal=Liberty & Law | year=2006 | month=August | volume=15 | issue=4}} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Further reading== * {{cite book | title=The Right Guide: A Guide to Conservative, Free-Market, and Right-of-Center Organizations | publisher=Economics America, Inc. | author=Wilcox, Derk Arend | year=2000 | location=Ann Arbor, MI | pages=455 | isbn=978-0-914169-06-2}} ==External links== {{colbegin}} *[http://www.theihs.org/ Institute for Humane Studies website] *[http://www.facebook.com/InstituteforHumaneStudies Institute for Humane Studies Facebook page] {{colend}} {{George Mason University}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Institute For Humane Studies}} [[Category:Organizations established in 1961]] [[Category:1961 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:George Mason University]] [[Category:Libertarian organizations based in the United States]] [[Category:Non-profit organizations based in Virginia]] [[Category:Classical liberalism]] [[Category:501(c)(3) nonprofit organizations]] [[es:Institute for Humane Studies]]
